title: CStr should have a function like from_bytes_with_nul() that reads until the first '\0'

labels.name: T-libs-api
labels.description: Relevant to the library API team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: C-feature-request
labels.description: Category: A feature request, i.e: not implemented / a PR.

body:
When dealing with FFI (fixed char buffers in file formats that represent strings and passing fixed char buffers to C code to write  chars to them up to a given max len) I often find myself doing this:
```rust
let end = s.iter().position(|&b| b == 0).map_or(0, |i| i + 1);
CStr::from_bytes_with_nul(&s[..end])
```
Because if I pass the whole slice to it, it returns a `FromBytesWithNulError`.
There should be a function that combines both lines and read until the first `'\0'` byte in the slice.

Something like:
```rust
CStr::from_bytes_until_nul(slice)
```

And yes, I did write my own function for [my use case](http://dpaste.com/0AYEQXZ) but I find myself copying these two lines around into different projects dealing with FFI and I think it would make sense to have this (arguably) "basic functionality" in std's `CStr` :)
